citation.article-title: Halolamina pelagica gen. nov., sp. nov., a new member of the family Halobacteriaceae
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Halolamina [Ha.lo.la′mi.na. Gr. n. hals, halos salt; L. fem. n. lamina a thin slice; N.L. fem. n. Halolamina thin-slice-shaped salt (organism)].
Cells are pleomorphic and thin-slice-shaped under optimal growth conditions and stain Gram-negative.
Oxidase and catalase tests are positive.
Extremely halophilic, with growth occurring in media containing 1.4–5.1 M NaCl; known strains grow best at 3.4–3.9 M NaCl.
The optimum magnesium concentration varies between 0.01 and 0.05 M.
Temperatures of 25–50 °C and pH 5.5–9.5 support growth.
Sugars are metabolized, in some cases with the formation of acids.

The polar lipids are phosphatidic acid, phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol phosphate methyl ester, phosphatidylglycerol sulfate and eight glycolipids; three of these glycolipids are chromatographically identical to S-DGD-1, TGD-1 and DGD-1.
The genomic DNA G+C content is 62.7–64.8 mol%.
Known strains have been isolated from marine solar salterns.
The type species is Halolamina pelagica.
